conclusion: To solve the problem, I will analyze the motion of the carts and bullets, focusing on the time intervals and distances involved. I will calculate the relative speed of the carts and use this to determine the time interval between bullet firings. Finally, I will derive the distance between two adjacent bullets.

The image shows two carts on a horizontal track. Cart A is moving left with speed \( v_1 \), and Cart B is moving right with speed \( v_2 \). Cart A has a gun that fires bullets horizontally at a constant speed \( v_0 \). Each bullet hits a target on Cart B, and the distance between two adjacent bullets in the air is \( s \).

premise: Cart A is moving left with speed \( v_1 \), and Cart B is moving right with speed \( v_2 \).
conclusion: The relative speed of Cart A and Cart B is \( v_1 - v_2 \).

premise: The speed of each bullet relative to the ground remains constant at \( v_0 \).
conclusion: The time interval \( \Delta t \) between firing bullets is determined by the distance \( s \) and the speed \( v_0 \) of the bullets: \( \Delta t = \frac{s}{v_0} \).

premise: Cart A is moving left with speed \( v_1 \).
conclusion: The distance \( s \) is also the distance traveled by Cart A during \( \Delta t \): \( s = v_1 \cdot \Delta t \).

premise: Substitute \( \Delta t = \frac{s}{v_0} \) into the equation for \( s \): \( s = v_1 \cdot \Delta t \).
